titleStmt.title: Controlled vocabulary for places in MedCyprus project, both monuments (churches) and repositories (museums)

desc.desc: 1st layer: late 12th century (naos: north crossarm, east wall)
2nd layer: 13th century (naos: north crossarm, west, north and east wall; west crossarm, north wall)
3rd layer: 14th century (naos: west crossarm, south wall)
4th layer: second half of the 15th century (naos: west crossarm, north wall)

place.desc: Anchorite cell and burial place; pilgrimage

desc.desc: 1st layer: 10th century (naos: north wall, above the tomb; north wall, eastern side).
2nd layer: undetermined; prior to the 13th-14th century (naos: north wall, eastern side)
3rd layer: 13th-14th century? First half of the 14th century? (bema; naos: east, north and west wall; ceiling)

place.desc: Fragmentary; condition poor. Conservation/cleaning: 1990-1991, 1993, 2002, 2005-2006 (DAC). Some of the paintings of the 1st layer have been removed to the Byzantine Museum of the Cultural Foundation Archbishop Makarios III.
Single-aisled vaulted church; later additions: south lateral aisle (12th-13th century?) and western open porch (14th-15th century?)

desc.desc: 1st layer: late 12th century (naos: south wall, western side; west wall)
2nd layer: 13th century? (naos: west wall; north wall, central recess?)

place.desc: Fragmentary. Some of the murals were illegally detached from the walls following 1974; current location unknown

desc.date: 11th century or early 12th century, with later additions

place.desc: Domed pier cross-in-square church; domed-hall narthex subsequently added to the west (12th or 13th century)

desc.desc: 13th-14th century (naos)

place.desc: Very fragmentary; badly preserved. Conservation/cleaning: 2020 (Bishopric of Karpasia)
Single-aisled barrel-vaulted church; narthex with drumless dome subsequently added to the west

desc.desc: 1st layer: early 13th century (naos: north and south wall)
2nd layer: late 13th century? (naos: south wall)
1st layer: 11th century (bema)
2nd layer: early 12th century (bema)

place.desc: Partially preserved; after 1974, some murals mutilated, others detached. Conservation/cleaning: 1972 (DAC), 2009 (USAID/SAVE)
Free-cross domed church; western crossarm subsequently extended westwards

desc.desc: 1st layer: 13th century?; (west crossarm: south wall)
2nd layer: 15th century?; overpainted in the 20th century (bema; central bay and dome; north and south crossarms

place.desc: Murals of 1st layer, very fragmentary. Conservation/cleaning: 1996, 1997 (DAC)
Domed-hall church; narthex subsequently added to the west (16th century)

desc.desc: First half of the 13th century (bema; dome; naos)

place.desc: Domed-hall church, with a later extension to the west; built on the ruins of a 7th-century three-aisled basilica

desc.desc: 1st layer: 12th century (bema; naos)
2nd layer: First half of the 16th century (bema; dome; naos)

place.desc: Badly damaged; very fragmentary. Conservation/cleaning: late 1940s, 1998, 2003, 2004, 2008, 2011, 2013-2015, 2017 (DAC)
1st layer: unknown. 2nd layer: Sabbas with his family (1509); Hilarion the monk (1552)
Domed-hall church (today, ruinous), with narthex subsequently added to the west (12th century)

desc.desc: 12th century (narthex)

place.desc: Fragmentary; very poorly preserved. One mural detached and displayed in the Ecclesiastical Museum of Sotera.
Domed-hall church, with twin apses inscribed into the eastern curved wall; narthex subsequently added to the west

desc.desc: 1st layer: 11th century (bema)
2nd layer: 13th century (naos: south central recess)
3st layer: 13th or 14th century (naos: cental bay)
4th layer: 15th century (naos: western bay)

place.desc: Male and female donors, lay and ecclesiastic, donated votive panels throughout the Byzantine and medieval period: 2nd layer: the priest Georgios and Magdalene . 3rd layer: Theodosia , one monk (Leontios), and at least another male donor . 4th layer: female donor (portrait; no inscription surviving)
Domed-hall(?) church, with south chapel added subsequently

desc.desc: Early 12th century (bema)

place.desc: Fragmentary; murals detached, now displayed in the Ecclesiastical Museum of the Holy Bishopric of Paphos. Conservation/cleaning: 1992, 2001 (DAC)
Single-cell chapel, partially carved into the rock (built sections of north, south and west walls do not survive)

desc.desc: 10th century (naos)

place.desc: Free-cross domed church; western extension of aisles, narthex, and northeastern naos compartment added subsequently (13th century?)

desc.desc: 1st layer: Philotheou, Petrou: 11th century; MedCyprus: 13th century (naos: south crossarm, east wall)
2nd layer: Early 13th century (naos: north and south crossarms)
3rd layer: Late 13th century (narthex)
4th layer: 15th century (dome; naos: north and south crossarms, western vault)
5th layer: 1896 (naos: north and south crossarms)

place.desc: Five-domed basilica, with a small domed tetraconch attached to its southeast corner; narthex subsequently added to the west (19th century)

desc.desc: 1st layer: 8th or 9th century (eastern dome above bema)
2nd layer: 10th century (nave)
3rd layer: Early 12th century (bema; nave)
4th layer: 14th century (nave; south aisle)
5th layer: Late 15th - Early 16th century (bema; central and western domes of nave; nave)

place.placeName: Gialia, Monastery of Panagia Chrysogialiotissa, main church
place.desc: Domed triconch church (today, ruinous), with northwest chapel of Saint George and western porch extending in front of both main church and chapel added subsequently

desc.desc: 1st layer: second half of 11th century (bema; naos)
2nd layer: first half of 12th century (western porch)

place.desc: Very fragmentary; poorly preserved. Fragments of painted plaster revealed during excavations are kept in the Archaeological Museum of Marion-Arsinoe. Conservation/cleaning: 2011, 2013, 2015 (DAC?)

place.placeName: Gialia, Monastery of Panagia Chrysogialiotissa, Saint George chapel
Γιαλιά, Παναγία Χρυσογιαλιώτισσα, παρεκκλήσιο Αγίου Γεωργίου
place.desc: Domed-hall chapel, annexed to the northwest of the main church of the monastery

desc.desc: 1st layer: first half of 12th century (naos; western porch)

place.desc: very fragmentary; poorly preserved. Fragments of painted plaster revealed during excavations are kept in the Archaeological Museum of Marion-Arsinoe. Conservation/cleaning: 2011, 2013, 2015 (DAC?)

place.placeName: Kakopetria, Saint Nicholas of the Roof
place.desc: Domed pier cross-in-square church, with narthex subsequently added (12th century); the saddleback timber roof covering both was in place by the 13th century

desc.desc: 1st layer: 11th century (bema; naos: western crossarm)
2nd layer: early 12th century (walled entrance to the diakonikon)
3rd layer: 12th century(naos: southwestern corner bay; narthex: central and north bays)
4th layer: 13th-14th century (naos: north crossarm; narthex)
5th layer: 14th century (bema; dome; naos: south crossarm; narthex)
6th layer: 15th century (naos: north crossarm; narthex: central bay)
7th layer: 1633 (naos: eastern piers, west face)

place.desc: Fragmentary; good condition. Murals of the 4th layer (14th century) from the bema were detached and are now displayed in the Byzantine Museum of the Cultural Foundation Archbishop Makarios III. Conservation/cleaning: 1966, 1968-1975, 1986, 1987, 1992, 2007 (DAC)

2nd layer: monk, whose name has been purposfully erased, but whose portrait survives 4th layer: one John and his wife (MedCY.018.045); John Triphyles, with his wife and their children, including his son Paskales 5th layer: the monk Nikon (inscription and portrait in the southwest recess of the narthex) 7th layer: the priest-monk Philotheos (portrait and inscription)

Original structure of uncertain type, since only part of the north wall survives incorporated into the present-day two-aisled timber roofed church, which was constructed in the 14th/15th century and expanded in the early 20th century

desc.desc: 1st layer: early 12th century (prothesis; naos: northwestern recess)
2nd layer: 15th century (naos: central recess of north wall)

place.desc: Domed octagon church, with narthex and south portico added subsequently (16th century)

desc.desc: 1st layer: late 12th century (bema; naos)
2nd layer: late 15th century (naos: north and south walls)
3rd layer: 17th century (narthex)

place.desc: Prior to 1974, good state of preservation; after 1974, the murals were mutilated and/or detached and illegaly exported; some were repatriated and are now kept in the Byzantine Museum of the Cultural Foundation Archbishop Makarios III. Conservation/cleaning: 1962, 1969, 1971-1972 (DAC)

place.placeName: Kalopanagiotis, Monastery of Saint John Lampadistes, chapel of Saint John Lampadistes
Kalopanagiotes, Monastery of Saint John Lampadistes, chapel of Saint John Lampadistes
Καλοπαναγιώτης, Μονή Αγίου Ιωάννη Λαμπαδιστή, παρεκκλήσιο Αγίου Ιωάννη Λαμπαδιστή
place.desc: Originally, a single-aisled structure, either vaulted or domed, attached to the north of the church of Saint Herakleidios, to house the tomb of the saint; today, only the eastern part of the north wall survives, incorporated into a later structure of the 18th century

place.placeName: Kalopanagiotis, Monastery of Saint John Lampadistes, church of Saint Herakleidios
Kalopanagiotes, Monastery of Saint John Lampadistes, church of Saint Herakleidios
Καλοπαναγιώτης, Μονή Αγίου Ιωάννη Λαμπαδιστή, ναός Αγίου Ηρακλειδίου
place.desc: Parochial(?). Currently, the main church (katholikon) of the monastery; whether its original function was monastic remains probable, but uncertain.
Domed pier cross-in-square church, with the chapel of Saint John Lampadistes, the so-called chapel of the Akathistos Hymn, and the narthex added subsequently (15th century)

desc.desc: 1st layer: 11th century (bema)
2nd layer: 12th century (bema)
3rd layer: second half of 13th century (dome; naos: central bay, south vault, west crossarm, west wall)
4th layer: early 15th century (bema; prothesis; diakonikon; naos: north crossarm, north wall, northwestern and southwestern compartments, south wall)
5th layer: second half of 15th century (narthex)

place.desc: Fragmentary. The murals of the 3rd-5th layers survive in good condition. Conservation/cleaning: 1968-1973, 2001 (DAC), 2007-2012 (Courtauld Institute of Art)
2nd layer: pair of anonymous monks, whose portrait survives in the bema. 5th layer: one Michael, who was an ecclesiastical official, his wife and his two sons, who were priests
5th layer: a refugee from Constantinople after 1453 (fragmentary inscription; his name does not survive)
Rock-cut, single-cell church, with three shallow niches carved into the eastern wall

desc.desc: 1st layer: early 12th century (east wall, below the three niches)
2nd layer: late 12th or early 13th century (east wall; south wall: east end; north wall: east end)

place.desc: On the south wall, a fragmentary incised inscription on the plaster mentions one Leontios, monk and abbot of the monastery; whether or not he was involved in the decoration of the church is unclear (prior to the execution of the 2nd layer of painted decoration)

desc.date: By the 13th century, when the painted decoration was executed. There are no structural features to indicate when the natural(?) cave was converted into a chapel.

desc.desc: 13th century (bema)

place.desc: Fragmentary; poor state of preservation. Fragments of murals were detached and are now kept in storage at the Department of Antiquities, Cyprus. Conservation/cleaning: 2002-2008 (DAC)
Domed-hall church, with narthex added subsequently (20th century)

desc.desc: 1st layer: late 12th century - early 13th century (bema; dome; naos: south central recess, southwestern recess)
2nd layer: 15th century (naos: west vault)
3rd layer: early 20th century (naos: north central recess, nothwestern recess)

place.desc: 1st layer: one supplicatory inscription in the bema makes reference to the priest Michael (son of?) Pileas, who may have contributed to the decoration of the church ; a second fragmentary inscription in the naos that makes reference to the wife(?) of one Sakellares is in all probability a funerary one .

desc.date: Prior to the late 12th century (date of 1st layer of painted decoration)

place.desc: Chamber of a Hellenestic(?) rock-cut tomb, converted into a single-cell chapel

desc.desc: 1st layer: Papageorgiou, Stylianou: late 12th century Hatfield Young, Konstandinidi: 14th century (bema)
2nd layer: 14th century (naos)

place.desc: 1st layer(?): a fragmentary inscription makes reference to a priest and caretaker of the church. Whether he was a donor remains unclear.
Originally, a domed pier cross-in-square church; extensively rebuilt in the 15th century; south porch added at an unknown date

desc.desc: 1st layer: late 9th or early 10th century (naos: piers originally supporting the dome)
2nd layer: 11th century (naos: west wall)
3rd layer: early 12th century (naos: soffits of arches connecting western piers with west wall)
4th layer: second half of 12th century (naos: piers originally supporting the dome)
5th layer: late 12th - early 13th century (naos: piers originally supporting the dome, vaults of north and south crossarms)

place.desc: Partially preserved. Some of the murals have been detached and are now on display at the Museum of the Kykkos Monastery. Conservation/cleaning: 1977, 1980-2000, 2002-2005, 2007-2008 (DAC)
A number of fragmentary inscriptions survive associated with votive panels of the 4th and 5th layers of painted decoration, see

desc.date: Late 11th or 12th century, with later additions: north chapel dedicated to Sts Kosmas and Damian, late 12th or early 13th century; south, "Latin" chapel, late 13th century; western extension, 19th century?

place.desc: Domed pier cross-in-square church, incorporating the apse of an Early Byzantine basilica (5th century?) to the east, with the north and south chapels and western extension added subsequently

desc.desc: 1st layer: 13th century (bema; naos: eastern and southwestern piers; north chapel)
2nd layer: 14th century (north chapel)
3rd layer: 15th or sixteenth century (north chapel)

place.desc: Fragmentary. Condition varies, from well to poorly preserved. Conservation/cleaning: 1965, 1972, 1975, 1979, 1983-1984, 1995 (DAC)

1st layer: one Leo or Leontios associated with the panel of St John the Baptist on the northwestern pier of the naos. 3rd layer: poorly preserved portrait of male(?) donor associated with mural of Sts Kosmas and Damian in the northwester recess of the north chapel.
Domed-hall church with elongated eastern and western bays, built on the remains of an Early Byzantine basilica (7th century?)

desc.desc: 1st layer: second half of 12th century (bema; naos: north and south walls)
2nd layer: late 14th century (naos: north and south walls)
3rd layer: 16th century (naos: south central recess)

place.desc: Fragmentary; poor state of preservation. Conservation/cleaning: 1950, 1975, 1999, 2011-2013 (DAC)

1st layer: a fragmentary inscription above the south door preserves a reference to a male donor . 2nd layer: a fragmentary inscription identifies the male donor of the mural of an archangel in the north central recess of the naos as Sampson(?) (son) of Plounteas

desc.desc: 1st layer: Chotzakoglou: late 12th century - early 13th century; Papageorgiou: 14th or 15th century (bema; naos)

place.desc: Fragmentary; poorly preserved. After 1974, sections of the murals were detached by looters; their current location is unknown. Conservation/cleaning: 1967 (DAC)

desc.desc: 1st layer: 8th century (bema; naos: north wall)
2nd layer: 9th century (bema; naos: vault, north and south walls)

place.desc: Fragmentary; poorly preserved. After 1974, sections of the murals were detached by looters and illegally exported abroad. Conservation/cleaning: 1967 (DAC)
Free-cross domed church, with elongated eastern crossarm; western crossarm subsequently replaced with extant structure and south porch subsequently added

desc.desc: 1st layer: Papageorgiou: 12th century, repainted in the 14th; all other scholars: 14th century (naos)
2nd layer: 15th or 16th century (dome; naos)

place.placeName: Koutsoventis, Monastery of Saint John Chrysostom, Holy Trinity chapel
Koutsovendes, Monastery of Saint John Chrysostom, Holy Trinity chapel
Κουτσοβέντης, Μονή Αγίου Ιωάννη Χρυσοστόμου, Παρεκκλήσιο Αγίας Τριάδος
Exarchate of the Holy Sepulchre in Cyprus
place.desc: Domed-hall church, with vaulted narthex to the west

desc.desc: ca 1100 (bema; dome; naos; narthex)

place.desc: Fragmentary; up to 1974, good condition. After 1974, the monument became inaccessible, so the condition of the murals cannot be evaluated. Conservation/cleaning: 1963-1969 (Dumbarton Oaks)
The doux of Cyprus, Eumathios Philokales (MedCY.033.001, )

place.placeName: Koutsoventis, Monastery of Saint John Chrysostom, Panagia Aphendrika
Koutsovendes, Monastery of Saint John Chrysostom, Panagia Aphendrika
Κουτσοβέντης, Μονή Αγίου Ιωάννη Χρυσοστόμου, Παναγία Αφέντρικα
Exarchate of the Holy Sepulchre in Cyprus
place.desc: Domed-hall chapel (today, ruinous), attached to the north side of the chapel of the Saviour

desc.desc: late 12th or early 13th century (naos: north wall, southwest recess)

place.desc: Fragmentary; prior to to 1974, fair condition. After 1974, the monument became inaccessible, so the condition of the murals cannot be evaluated. Conservation/cleaning: 1956 (DAC)

place.placeName: Koutsoventis, Monastery of Saint John Chrysostom, Saviour
Koutsovendes, Monastery of Saint John Chrysostom, Saviour
Κουτσοβέντης, Μονή Αγίου Ιωάννη Χρυσοστόμου, Παρεκκλήσιο του Σωτήρος Χριστού
Exarchate of the Holy Sepulchre in Cyprus
place.desc: Domed-hall church (today, ruinous), with narthex added subsequently to the west and the chapel of Panagia Aphendrika added to the north

desc.desc: early 12th century (bema; naos: north wall)

place.desc: Fragmentary; prior to to 1974, fair condition. After 1974, the monument became inaccessible, so the condition of the murals cannot be evaluated. Conservation/cleaning: 1930s, 1956 (DAC)

desc.date: Second half of 12th century (AD 1192 terminus ante quem)

place.desc: Domed-hall church, with an apsidal narthex added subsequently to the west (ca 1200); the narthex was replaced by the one extant today in the late 18th century

desc.desc: 1st layer: 1170s (bema: apse)
2nd layer: 1192 (bema; dome; naos)
3rd layer: ca 1332/3 (narthex: east wall; exterior of north wall: lunette above north door)
4th layer: first half of 17th century (exterior of north wall)

place.desc: 2nd layer: A fragmentary inscription mentioning a monk, whose name has been reconstructed as Theodore, has been interpreted as refering to the painter, which some scholars identify with Theodore Apseudes (MedCY.036.185). 3rd layer: Leontios the Deacon

desc.date: Late 11th - Early 12th century, with later additions

place.desc: Domed pier cross-in-square church, built over the nave of an Early Byzantine basilica and incorporating its eastern central apse; domed narthex added during the 12th century to the west; exonarthex and western porch added subsequently (15th/16th century)

desc.desc: first half of 12th century (bema)

place.desc: Fragmentary; poor state of preservation. Conservation/cleaning: -

desc.date: 12th century; extensively rebuilt in the 14th century

desc.desc: 1st layer: 13th century (bema: apse wall; naos: southwestern pier, soffits of arches connecting western piers to the west wall)
2nd layer: 15th century (bema; naos)
early 13th century (bema; dome)

place.desc: Fragmentary; very good state of preservation. Sometime between 1974 and 1983 the murals were detached by looters to be sold abroad. In 1984 they were obtained by the Menil Foundation on behalf of the Church of Cyprus and were put on display at the Menil Collection, Houston TX. In 2012 the murals were repatriated and are now on housed in the Byzantine Museum of the Cultural Foundation Archbishop Makarios III. Conservation/cleaning: 1972 (DAC), 1984-1988 (Menil Foundation)

desc.date: After the middle of the 7th century, with subsequent building phases in the 9th, 12th, and 13th/14th centuries

place.desc: Pier, vaulted, three-aisled basilica, incorporating the central apse of an Early Byzantine column basilica, with a dome over the central nave and a drumless dome above the bema, a narthex to the west with a dome over its central bay, and a porch to the south. Form, the result of successive, difficult-to-date building phases.

desc.desc: 1st layer: 8th century (nave)
2nd layer: second half of 9th century - first half of 10th century (bema; nave)
3rd layer: 12th century (bema; nave)
4th layer: ca 1500 (bema; dome; nave; aisles; south porch)

place.desc: 2nd layer: a fragmentary painted inscription on the southwest pier makes mention of one deacon(?) John, the archbishop Theodore(?) (of Cyprus?), the patriarch(?) Solomon of Jerusalem (ca 860-865), and one Eustathius; the nature of their involvement with the church is unclear. 4th layer: portrait of a man and a woman, either his (deceased?) wife or daughter, on the lunette above the south door; neither their names nor their relation survive in the fragmentary inscription that accompanies the portrait.

desc.date: 12th century, with subsequent interventions in the 15th/16th century

place.desc: Domed-hall church, built over the nave of a three-aisled domed basilica of the 7th/8th century; at a later unknown date, the western bay was truncated.

desc.desc: 1st layer: 12th century (naos)
2nd layer: late 15th century - early 16th century (dome and pendentives)

place.placeName: Monagri, Monastery of Panagia Amasgou, main church
place.desc: Single-aisled barrel-vaulted church, with a second, timber gable roof.

desc.desc: 1st layer: early 12th century (bema)
2nd layer: late 12th century - early 13th century (bema; naos)
3rd layer: first half of 14th century (naos: west bay)
4th layer: first half of 15th century (naos: north wall)
5th layer: 1564 (bema; naos)

place.desc: Fragmentary; good condition. Conservation/cleaning: 1960 (DAC), 1969-1972 (Dumbarton Oaks), 1990 (DAC), 1992-1994, 1997, 2009 (Courtauld Institute of Art)
Single-aisled timber-roofed church, with an L-shaped closed portico along its northern and western sides.

desc.desc: 1st layer: July 30, 1280 (bema; naos; exterior of west wall)
2nd layer: early 14th century (naos: south wall; exterior of west wall)
3rd layer: late 15th century - early 16th century (exterior of north wall)

place.desc: 1st layer: Ioannes Gerakiotes and his wife Irene funded the construction and the mural decoration of the church (MedCY.043.020, MedCY.043.020). Christophoros Omotes and his wife Maria funded the mural panel of Saint Christopher on the south wall of the naos (MedCY.043.036). Another couple, Georgios Kompotes and his wife Eirene, funded the mural panel with the enthroned Christ on the exterior of the west wall .
Single-aisled, barrel-vaulted church, with a second, timber gable roof; an apsidal narthex with a domical vault was subseqently added to the west (mid- to late 12th century)

desc.desc: 1st layer: 1105/6 (bema; naos: west bay; narthex: above entrance into the naos, originally exterior of west wall; exterior of north wall)
2nd layer: last quarter of 12th century (narthex: south apse; east wall on either side of door into naos)
3rd layer: late 12th century - before 1332/3 (narthex: north apse, below mural icon of Archangel Michael)
4th layer: last quarter of 13th century (bema; naos: western pilasters; narthex: south apse)
5th layer: 1332/3 (narthex)
6th layer: 1340s (naos: central bay)
7th layer: 16th century (naos: east face of northwest pilaster)
8th layer: 1618-1640 (bema)

place.desc: Fragmentary; very good state of preservation. Conservation/cleaning: 1954-1955 (DAC), 1965-1967 (Dumbarton Oaks), 1995-1996 (DAC)

1st layer: the magistros Nikephoros Ischyrios (MedCY.044.004, MedCY.044.053, MedCY.044.061). The association of a female relation of the donor named Gefyra, mentioned in a funerary inscription (MedCY.044.054), to the foundation and decoration of the church remains unclear. 2nd layer: Nikephoros (son) of Kalleas MedCY.044.104, MedCY.044.105). 4th layer: Anastasia Saramalyna (MedCY.044.107); a Latin family, comprising of a woman and her two sons, funded the mural of the Virgin of Mercy in the conch of the south apse of the narthex (portrait; no inscription survives). 5th layer: the monk Theophilos and "the common people"; at least ten portraits of monks, including Theophilos, and lay men and women survive in the narthex, with their accompanying inscriptions.

desc.date: 12th century, with narthex subsequently added (by the 13th century); naos extensively rebuilt in the 16th century

place.desc: Single-aisled vaulted church, with a sail-vault narthex to the west

desc.desc: 1st layer: late 13th century (narthex)
2nd layer: 16th century (bema; naos; narthex)

place.desc: 1st layer: a Latin family, consting of the parents and at least two children, funded the mural of a Latin saintly prelate (portrait; no inscription survives)

desc.date: 13th century, with major reconstruction in the 19th and early 20th centuries

place.desc: Originally, a domed pier cross-in-square church, of which only the tripartite sanctuary survives incorporated into the 19th-century church that has replaced the original structure

desc.desc: 1st layer: first half of 13th century (bema: arches leading to the prothesis and the diakonikon)

place.desc: Fragmentary; good state of preservation. Conservation/cleaning: 2007 (DAC)

desc.date: 11th century, with subsequent additions (12th century: narthex)

place.desc: Single-aisled vaulted church, with a sail-vault narthex subsequently added to the west

desc.desc: 1st layer: 11th century (naos)
2nd layer: late 12th century (bema; naos: north wall; narthex; exterior west wall of narthex)

place.desc: Fragmentary; poor state of preservation; covered in soot. Conservation/cleaning: 2000 (DAC)

desc.date: 12th century, prior to 1170s (1st layer of mural decoration), with subsequent alterations and additions in the 13th/14th and the 15th/16th centuries

place.desc: Form of original single-aisled church uncertain; currently, a domed-hall church, incororating the apse and lower parts of the naos walls of the 12th-century structure (late 13th/early 14th century), flanked by "chapels"/aisles to the south (late 13th/early 14th century) and the north (14th century) that were expanded to their present width in the 15th/16th century.

desc.desc: 1st layer: 1178 (bema: apse)
2nd layer: 13th century (bema: east wall to the south of the apse; south aisle: north wall)
3rd layer: Zarras: second quarter of 14th century; Hadjichristodoulou: third quarter of 14th century(bema; dome; naos)
4th layer: 3rd quarter of the 14th century (north aisle)
5th layer: 14th - 15th century (south aisle: west wall)
6th layer: early 16th century (naos: south wall)

place.desc: Fragmentary; on the whole, good state of preservation; the murals of the 12th century bear extensive hammer marks to prepare the surface for a new painted layer; the 14th-century murals of the bema apse were detached by DAC and relocated to the east wall of the south chapel. Conservation/cleaning: 1972, 1982-1983, 1985-1994, 2002-2003, 2008 (DAC)

1st layer: the priest Georgios, along with the other priests of the village (MedCY.048.001) 3rd layer: no names survive in the fragmentary dedicatory inscription above the western entrance to the naos. Three funerary portraits of lay men and women, accompanied by inscriptions, on the walls of the naos and on the western facade (lunette above the door); whether they and/or their families contributed to the decoration of the church remains unclear. 4th layer: portrait of Latin donors(?), identified by modern scholars, on the basis of the coat-of-arms accompanying the portrait, as Jean de Lusignan (d. 1375) and his wife; funerary portrait of one Leon Skouleas, whose potential contribution to the decoration of the north aisle remains unclear. 6th layer: portrait of a family, consisting of the parents and at least one child, on the south wall of the naos, by the templon (no inscription survives)
1st layer: a painter surnamed Mon[o]machos; his first name no longer survives (MedCY.048.001)

desc.date: around the middle of the 12th century

desc.desc: 1st layer: 1160-1180 (bema; dome; naos)
2nd layer: 15th century (naos: south wall)

place.desc: Fairly good condition; at points, where the surface paint does not survive, the underpaint is visible. Conservation/cleaning: 1954 (DAC), 1959-1960 (DAC/Byzantine Institute), 1969, 1980, 1998, 2010 (DAC)

desc.date: Papacostas: late 11th / first half of 12th century

place.desc: Five-domed three-aisled basilica, built on the remains of an Early Byzantine basilica; narthex subsequently added to the west (12th century?)

desc.desc: 1st layer: 13th century (nave: northeast pier, southwest pier, eastern piers supporting central dome)
2nd layer: 16th century (nave: northwest pier supporting the central dome)

place.desc: 2nd layer: a funerary inscription makes reference to one priest Solomos(?), however his association with the decoration of the church remains unclear.

desc.date: 12th century, with subsequent alterations and additions (15th century, 18th century)

place.desc: Domed-hall church, with narthex subsequently added to the west (15th century). A larger, single-aisled vaulted church was added to the south in 1723.

desc.desc: 12th century (bema; dome: pendentives; naos)

place.desc: Very fragmentary; some murals bear hammer marks. Conservation/cleaning: 2012-2013 (DAC)
Single-aisled vaulted church, with a now ruinous narthex subsequently added to the west (date unknown)

desc.desc: 1st layer: Papageorgiou: 12th century; Chotzakoglou: 13th century (bema; naos)
2nd layer: 13th century or later (naos: north central recess; southwest recess)

place.desc: Fragmentary; poor state of preservation. Conservation/cleaning: 1967 (DAC)

place.placeName: Sichari, Monastery of Panagia Apsinthiotissa, main church
Sychari, Monastery of Panagia Apsinthiotissa, main church
Exarchate of the Holy Sepulchre in Cyprus

desc.date: ca 1100, with subsequent additions and alterations (12th, 14th, 15th centuries)

place.desc: Variation of the simple domed octagon church, with six supports instead of eight; apsidal narthex subsequently added to the west (12th century)

desc.desc: 1st layer: ca 1100 (bema; naos)
2nd layer: second half of 12th century (narthex)
3rd layer: 14th century (naos)
4th layer: 15th/16th century (bema; narthex)

place.desc: Very fragmentary; poor state of preservation. During restoration work in the 1960s, the mural of St Ignatios (3rd layer) was transferred from the northeast pier supporting the dome, to the southeast, in order to reveal earlier murals. After 1974, the murals sufferred serious damage, while sections were detached by looters and illegally exported abroad. Conservation/cleaning: 1963-1964, 1968, 1971 (DAC)

place.placeName: Sichari, Monastery of Panagia Apsinthiotissa, refectory
Sychari, Monastery of Panagia Apsinthiotissa, refectory
Exarchate of the Holy Sepulchre in Cyprus
place.desc: Groin-vaulted rectangular hall, with an apse to the east

desc.desc: early 12th century (apse)

place.desc: Very fragmentary; very poor state of preservation. Conservation/cleaning: 1964, 1966 (DAC)

desc.date: 12th century - early 13th century, with subsequent additions and alterations (15th/16th and 19th centuries)

place.desc: Currently, a domed-hall church, resulting from the remodeling of an earlier (8th century?) single-aisled structure built over the nave of an Early Byzantine basilica; an annex of uncertain date was constructed along the south side of the church, later concealed by the 19th-century south portico.

desc.desc: 1st layer: 8th or 9th century (naos: behind the southeast pilaster)
2nd layer: 12th or early 13th century (naos: north recesses on either side of the dome; northeast pilaster supporting the dome)
3rd layer: last third of 13th century (prothesis; naos: east vault, central bay, west vault, west wall?)
4th layer: 16th century (prothesis; naos: western pilasters supporting the dome)
5th layer: 19th century (bema; prothesis)

place.desc: Fragmentary; fair condition, though the lower parts of some of the murals on the north wall were damaged by humidity. Conservation/cleaning: 1989, 1991, 1996, 1998-2000, 2002, 2008, 2016 (DAC)
3rd layer: one, possibly two portraits of male supplicants on the north wall; in the absence of surviving inscriptions, their potential contribution to the decoration of the church remains unclear

desc.date: 12th century, with subsequent alterations and remodelling (14th, 16th centuries)

place.desc: Currently, a three-aisled vaulted basilica, the result of major reconstruction in the 1970s by DAC. Originally, the church may have been a cross-in-square building

desc.desc: 1st layer: 12th century (nave)
2nd layer: 16th century (bema; nave)

place.desc: Very fragmentary; during the 20th-century reconstruction of the vaulting, ashlars from the site bearing fragments of murals were employed in no particular order. Ashlars bearing mural fragments are also kept in the Archaeological Museum of Marion-Arsinoe. Conservation/cleaning: -

desc.date: 13th century(?), with major remodelling in the 19th and 20th centuries

place.desc: Originally, a domed triconch or tetraconch; in 1817, the eastern apse was demolished and enlarged and the western part was also demolished and the church expanded to the west. What remained of the original church was incorporated into the modern church to serve as its sanctuary.

desc.desc: 1st layer: late 13th - early 14th century (dome; south conch: east wall [repainted in the 20th century])
2nd layer: 16th century (prothesis)
3rd layer: 20th century (south conch)

place.desc: Fragmentary; dome murals: fairly good state of preservation. Conservation/cleaning: 1981,1990, 2006, 2016 (DAC)
Domed pier cross-in-square church, built on the site and incorporating elements of an Early Byzantine basilica

desc.desc: 1st layer: 10th century (naos: only the inscription [MedCY.058.001] may be ascribed with certainty to this layer)
2nd layer: 14th century (diakonikon; naos: west piers, south wall)
3rd layer: 1887 (naos: southwest pier, north face)

place.desc: Fragmentary; very poor state of preservation; murals faded. After 1974, the face of a military saint on horseback on the south face of the northwestern pier was covered with plaster. Conservation/cleaning: -

1st layer: the potential contribution of the author/narrator of an extensive funerary inscription (MedCY.058.001) in the southwestern part of the church to the mural decoration is unclear. 3rd layer: fragmentary inscriptions mentions a male donor and his family; no names survive

desc.date: 1159/60: cell, also containing the tomb of Neophytos the Recluse, and the bema; 1183: naos; after 1170: narthex, hagiasterion (small space above the naos), New Zion (i.e., new cell, above the hagiasterion)

place.desc: Rock-cut complex, comprising the cell with the tomb, the bema, the trapezoidal naos, and the narthex

desc.desc: 1st layer: 1159/60 - 1183 (cell)
2nd layer: 1183 (bema; cell)
3rd layer: after 1197 - 1214 (death of Neophytos the Recluse) (naos)
4th layer: ca 1500 (narthex)
5th layer: 1503 (bema; naos)

place.desc: Very good state of preservation. Conservation/cleaning: 1963-1964, 1970 (Dumbarton Oaks), 1976,1984, 1987, 1989, 1992, 2005 (DAC)

1st - 3rd layers: Neophytos the Recluse, as attested by extant portraits and inscriptions in the complex, as well as by the writings of the saint 5th layer: the monk Neophytos, mentioned in an inscription in the naos

place.placeName: Tala, Hermitage of Saint Neophytos, refectory

desc.desc: 1st layer: ca 1200 (ceiling; east, west and south walls)
2nd layer: ca 1500 (ceiling; west wall)

place.desc: 1st layer: Neophytos the Recluse (though no inscription or portrait survives)
In ruins, original form uncertain; single-aisled vaulted structure.

desc.desc: 13th century (naos)

place.desc: Very fragmentary; poor state of preservation. Conservation/cleaning: 2004 (DAC). The surviving murals were detached and transferred to the conservation workshops of DAC in Paphos.

desc.date: Early 12th century, with subsequent additions and alterations (15th and 19th centuries)

place.desc: Originally, a domed-hall structure, though with cylindrical engaged piers supporting the dome; north aisle/"chapel" and successive western extensions subsequently added

desc.desc: 1st layer: early 12th century (bema; dome; naos)
2nd layer: 15th century (naos: southwest recess)
3rd layer: 16th century (north aisle)
4th layer: 1959 (prothesis)

place.desc: Fragmentary; good state of presevation. Conservation/cleaning: 1965-1966 (Greek Archaeological Service), 2008 (TCCH - unofficial emergency work)
1st layer: one donor (gender unclear) addresses a prayer to the Theotokos, but no name survives 4th layer: Andreas K. Prokopiou, along with his wife and their children

desc.desc: 12th century (bema; naos)

place.desc: Fragmentary; very poor state of preservation. Conservation/cleaning: 1973, 2008 (DAC)

place.placeName: Byzantine Museum of the Cultural Foundation Archbishop Makarios III
Βυζαντινό Μουσείο Πολιτιστικού Ιδρύματος Αρχιεπισκόπου Μακαρίου Γ'
Ecclesiastical Museum of the Holy Bishopric of Paphos
